metadata.purpose: Demonstrates native domain AKU for cross-domain pattern

definition.@value: A monad on a category C is a triple (T, η, μ) consisting of an endofunctor T: C → C together with two natural transformations η: 1_C → T (the unit) and μ: T² → T (the multiplication) satisfying the coherence conditions: μ ∘ Tμ = μ ∘ μT (associativity) and μ ∘ Tη = μ ∘ ηT = 1_T (unit laws).

components.μ: Multiplication natural transformation μ: T² → T

examples.name: Identity Monad
examples.description: T = 1_C (identity functor) with η = μ = identity

examples.name: Power Set Monad
examples.description: In Set, T = P (power set functor)

examples.name: Free Monoid Monad
examples.description: In Set, T maps a set to its free monoid (list of elements)

scopeNote.@value: This is the categorical definition of monad, not the computer science interpretation. For programming applications, see the 'cross_domain_applications' section below.

cross_domain_applications.note: This section documents where this mathematical concept is APPLIED. The applications themselves are AKUs in their respective domains that LINK to this definition.

applications.context: Monads structure effectful computations in functional programming languages
Monads provide semantics for computational effects in type theory
Monads appear in categorical quantum mechanics

provenance.historical_note: The monad concept was introduced by Roger Godement in 1958 (under the name 'standard construction') and developed further by many category theorists. The name 'monad' was introduced by Mac Lane.
